Born in Newark, New Jersey, Houston was the daughter of gospel singer Emily "Cissy" Houston and John Russell Houston Jr. She was raised in a musical family and began singing at a young age, performing in local talent shows and choirs.

Houston's music career began in the 1980s when she sang backup for artists such as Chaka Khan, Lou Rawls, and George Benson. Her big break came in 1983 when she sang "The Greatest Love of All" for the soundtrack of the film "The Greatest American Hero." Her powerful vocals and emotive delivery caught the attention of Arista Records, which signed her to a record deal.

Houston's debut album, "Whitney Houston," was released in 1985 and became a massive commercial success, selling over 25 million copies worldwide. The album spawned several hit singles, including "Saving All My Love for You," "How Will I Know," and "The Greatest Love of All." The album earned Houston four Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year, and established her as one of the most successful artists of the 1980s.

Houston's subsequent albums, including "Whitney" (1987), "I'm Your Baby Tonight" (1990), and "My Love Is Your Love" (1998), continued to produce hit singles and sold millions of copies worldwide. Her iconic songs, such as "I Will Always Love You," "I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)," and "I Have Nothing," have become an integral part of pop culture.

Houston's success extended beyond her music. She appeared in several films, including "The Bodyguard" (1992), "Waiting to Exhale" (1995), and "The Preacher's Wife" (1996). Her performances in these films earned her a Golden Globe nomination for Best Actress.

Throughout her career, Houston was recognized with numerous awards and accolades, including six Grammy Awards, two Emmy Awards, and 30 Billboard Music Awards. She was also inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2009.
